title: Medical Definition of Chickenpox immunization
author: Medical Editor Jay W Marks; MD
description: Read medical definition of Chickenpox immunization
cleaned_text: or lessen the severity of the common [disease](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3011) known as chickenpox. The [vaccination](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=5925) currently involves two shots, the first dose (shot) at age 12 through 15 months and the second dose (shot) at age 4 through 6 years. The second dose may be given at an earlier age if it is given at least 3 months after the first dose. People 13 years of age and older who have never had chickenpox or received chickenpox vaccine should get two doses, at least 28 days apart. [Chickenpox vaccination](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=21961) is especially important for [health](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3663) care professionals, people who care for or are around others with weakened [immune](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3905) systems, teachers, child care workers, residents and staff [in](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3950) nursing homes and residential settings, college students, inmates and staff of correctional institutions, Military personnel, non-pregnant women of child-bearing age, adolescents and adults living with children, international travelers. There have been few significant reactions to the chickenpox vaccine. All children, except those with a compromised [immune system](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=3907) or a known [neurological](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=11748) [condition](https://www.rxlist.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=10778), should have the vaccination.
